Award.AwardTitle: Isocyanide-Promoted Buchner Reaction of Ruthenium Carbenes: A Useful Mechanistic Tool to Study Ene-Yne and Alkene Metathesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the research of Professors Steven T. Diver and Jerome B. Keister. Professor Diver and Professor Keister are faculty members in the Department of Chemistry at the University at Buffalo, the State University of New York. Ene-yne metathesis is a metal-catalyzed reaction that brings together two molecules, one with a carbon-carbon double bond and the other with a carbon-carbon triple bond. The two molecules are linked together by the action of the catalyst. The reaction is widely used in organic synthesis and materials chemistry. The ene-yne reaction, however, is difficult to study and the selectivity is hard to predict. The goal of this project is to better understand the structure of the intermediates and the catalytic cycle. A better understanding of reactive intermediates facilitates the prediction of selectivity and the design of better catalysts. Graduate students and undergraduates are trained in organic, organometallic, and inorganic chemistry through their participation in the project. Additional outreach efforts at the elementary school level develop scientific awareness in eager young minds, and often give students their first exposure to the many roles of molecules in our world.

The Grubbs ruthenium carbenes have improved organic synthesis. Alkene metathesis and ene-yne metathesis are widely used in the synthesis of natural products, pharmaceuticals agents, and organic materials. However, decomposition of catalytic intermediates and low selectivity in cross metathesis are two fundamental problems that limit the efficiency and scope of these powerful reactions. In this collaborative project, a research team led by Drs. Diver and Keister are developing the Buchner reaction to trap reactive intermediates and thus study of mechanism of these reactions. Key questions center on the decomposition pathways and reactivity of ruthenium vinyl carbenes. The reactivity of substituted vinyl carbenes has not been evaluated previously, despite the importance of these intermediates in the ene-yne pathway. Quenching of metathesis reactions continues to be a problem and reliable, rapid methods for quenching a wide variety of ruthenium catalysts is an important goal of the project. Solid-supported isocyanides are being developed and used for the quenching and removal of ruthenium carbenes. Dr. Diver presents a molecular science course for non-majors at SUNY Buffalo that increases general scientific literacy of the University students.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Buffalo
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
“Isocyanide-Promoted Buchner Reaction of Ruthenium Carbenes: A Useful Mechanistic Tool to Study Ene-Yne and Alkene Metathesis” CHE-1566162

 

Project Outcomes

Intellectual Merits       Ene-yne metathesis is a catalytic, atom economical method for the construction of conjugated dienes from simple unsaturated starting materials, but the benefit of faster catalysts and the role of unique decomposition pathways is poorly understood. Conjugated dienes are easily transformed into useful molecules and can be used accordingly for the construction of complex molecules with medicinal properties. 

            Metal catalysis is widely used in diverse fields of chemistry and materials, but metal recovery from these reactions is unpredictable, difficult, inefficient and sometimes totally ineffective. In the industrial sector, large scale catalysis is used for the preparation of pharmaceuticals/medicines, but purification of drugs and drug intermediates from residual toxic metals is problematic. Since direct removal methods are lacking, time consuming work around strategies are needed, driving up costs. Improved metal removal may facilitate the drug-to-market process and lower overall costs to produce new drugs.

            This NSF project aimed to develop the isocyanide triggered Buchner reaction as a tool to arrest fast metal-catalyzed reactions and to permit the rapid and efficient removal of metals from the products. We used the isocyanide materials to remove metals such as Ru from alkene and ene-yne metathesis, but also other transition metals due to the strong binding interaction between isocyanide ligands and a wide variety of metals commonly used as catalysts. For most metals, the isocyanide binds strongly to the metal but does not trigger a Buchner reaction. Outcomes included an improved mechanistic picture of how faster initiators rapidly produce a steady state concentration of ruthenium vinyl carbenes and its relationship to catalyst decomposition in ene-yne metathesis; an enantioselective ring expansion ene-yne metathesis reaction; the use of a Co-catalyst for a mild diene isomerization reaction; the subsequent application of Ru and Co tandem catalysis to the synthesis of the polyketide subunit of the nannocystins; and an improved understanding of the scope and limitations of isocyanides supported on silica gel and polystyrene materials.

Broader Impacts         The most important broader impacts of this project included the training of future scientists. Participation in designing and testing new materials for quenching and removing metals has trained students in a broad range of problems addressing sustainability, recycling and economy of synthesis. The training of seven graduate students and three undergraduate students, representing a broad and diverse range of backgrounds, has helped achieve the project goals and prepared individuals to confront pressing scientific problems in their own future scientific careers.

 


Last Modified: 10/13/2020
Modified by: Steven T Diver
